comment.author: 58793889@N00
comment._content: There aren't many streets like this in Montreal, but you might find something like it in Lachine or Pointe-aux-Trembles: maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&q=R... There's a train line running down that linear park, houses and buildings on both sides.

comment.author: 29497963@N07
comment._content: It should be noted that these tracks we're used for tramways. So we're looking for a street that definitely had a tram in the middle. Best guess would be the streets in pointe-aux-trembles, since they are the ones that had a tram and not only a railway.

comment.author: 58793889@N00
comment._content: Oh good point. This could be the start of any main street being developed then – Villeray and Rosemont come to mind, where houses like that, with those cornices, are common.

comment.author: 29497963@N07
comment._content: This seems a little different though... like the street was on the side of the tracks. But you're right. it could be that the tracks became part of the street later on... Any idea when tetraultville and points north towards pointe-aux-trembles we're developped?

comment.author: 58793889@N00
comment._content: I'm not sure, but I imagine a lot of it was built up around the same time as Villeray, in the boom of streetcar extensions that made those areas easily accessible from downtown for the first time - the time after WWI and before the 1929 depression, mostly.
